displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: because weirdly enough it’s IV so it’s not a pill like what you’ve been on with all of your prior treatments. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: Anything else we’re missing? The other thing that’s hard about Xofigo though is that sometimes it doesn’t make the PSA go down. In fact, two-thirds of the people the PSA rises up and you’re like is this stuff in me, hello, are these guys pocketing it or what’s going on and it’s just something that happens bone wise that sometimes you just see almost the worsening of the PSA and yours is already going up so I bring that up so it won’t be like oh, my god, she’s ah, doesn’t she not know it’s higher. Patient: The conference we went to I learned about that. Doctor: Yes, you did. Patient: So that, that was well worth being there just for that. Doctor: Oh, I’m so glad. Patient: So I’m well aware of that. Doctor: Awesome. Patient: I told my kids that. I said, oh man, that’s, yeah, so I understand that. Doctor: Yeah, so you know it’s something we consider but just so you know we don’t combine the two, right.

Patient: I, yeah, I, um, for now on, I’m trying to do them here. I don’t want to --- Doctor: Are we doin’ it on the same day or are you coming in early or? Family Member: We should – they want you to come in early so they can have something – Patient: The appointment for the twenty-fifth, she wanted me to come in a few days earlier. The nurse was saying --- Family Member: A week early. Or Doctor: The same would be true for me in April, if you could do it early? Patient: Yeah, yeah. I will. Doctor: You could do it the same day, but then we don’t – Patient: No, I will. Doctor: But I just have to tell you about aliens, and I’ve got nothing else to talk to you about. Patient: Well, yeah, I know. I’ll get my daughter over here. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American
What race or races do you consider yours.American Indian or Alaska Native: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::American Indian or Alaska Native

displayed_text: Family Member: So this other doctor is going to explain the side effects he may get from radiation? Doctor: Yeah, so when you see Dr. B____, so that’s another Dr. B, you’re going to listen about what can or can’t you do, why is it once a month, what are your obligations. What are the potential side effects and how does he want to see you and he might need blood work kind of not on day of because there’s a half-life to the medicine as in if he knows the week before your counts are good to go then he can order it and when you show up it’s here and you get it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If he orders it and you show up and uh-oh you can’t get it, there’s, we’re in trouble. Patient: Right, Okay. Doctor: That’s fifteen thousand you might have to just flush down the toilet because you can’t save it for the next week because it starts to decay and you can’t give it to somebody else so. Patient: Okay, I’m good with that. That sounds good. Okay? Doctor: It’s okay. Patient: I happy with it. Doctor: Great. You guys had a lot of good questions today. Patient: We learned to ask. You got to speak up. That’s right. Doctor: You got to advocate for yourself. Right? That’s absolutely the one thing. So, very good. Patient: So, that’s good news that we can travel. I like being able to see the grandkids you know.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may, I don’t think we have an opening at Hospital B but that’s one of the sites that we collaborate with, and I think they had interest in opening it, and so we can check in to see whether they have that open. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But that would be clearly if we say I’m doing chemotherapy, do I want to do something more on top of it, so that would be one option. Experimentally we have two treatments, uh one based on the fact that your ARV7 is positive. We have an experimental study where we give everyone immune therapy, a doublet. That is a combination of two drugs that are approved in melanoma, soon to be approved in kidney cancer that can turn on your immune system to attack your cancer. It doesn’t work all that well so far in prostate cancer, maybe fifteen percent of people may get a benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh some data that said people who are on Enzalutamide stay on Enzalutamide and get these drugs uh may have a higher response rate, and that’s what we are testing. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have done this already in fifteen men and I think three people benefited for a period of time, relatively short. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But still benefited and so they did not have Enzalutamide or the Xtandi, so we’re doing fifteen more who have Xtandi uh and seeing whether or not it’s a higher response because of that.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And if it’s time we do it. You know? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If it’s like absolutely the same, then we’re just going to hang out. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, you know, kind of play around with pills and see if we can get it down. Family Member: Oh, okay. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But I need to be assured as you guys do also. Family Member: Right. Doctor: That there’s nothing new or that these guys all of a sudden didn’t wake up and go, yeah, well, we were sleeping. Family Member: Right. Doctor: All those lymph nodes and now we’re awake. And we would know if we’re awake because it would be bigger or if it was new. Like, wait a minute.

Family Member: Multi-grain, right, okay multi-grain. Okay, so that’s it. Now I know this is early and he’s feeling fine, but somebody brought it up and I want to ask you. When he starts radiation, chemotherapy is it possible to get the medical marijuana or how is that to happen? Patient: I never used my form, so we Family Member: And so we need to know in what form you know he should take Doctor: I hope he doesn’t need marijuana have an Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It’s only people who you know just have nausea that just can’t be controlled by medicines - Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Then we would use marijuana. Family Member: Okay, that’s what I was told - Family Member: Just to stop vomiting and that so she mentioned that her son um had cancer. And so she mentioned that and I said I will ask. Doctor: So any other questions? Family Member: No.

Patient: Uh. Clinical study? (Pause5sec) Patient: My one meds is I wasn’t so sure that I could take. Doctor: So, yeah, when we saw you, you already had Abiraterone, enzaluta – Radium, docetaxel. And, so what we do next, uh, you know, the only thing you haven’t had is, uh, chemotherapy. Uh, another chemotherapy called Radia, uh – Jevtana, cabazitaxel would be standard treatment you could go through, and we were waiting because again, you’d finished your chemo – um, and uh Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Um. So, uh. Patient: The enzalutamide. I, I don’t remember being on that. Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Yeah. We have to use the generic name. The, the drug company, they want the one that they want -- the fancy name. Um. So (Pause) Patient: Well, uh, the gentleman, M_, said he had one more chemo for me, but he didn’t have much faith it would do anything. So, maybe it was the same. Doctor: Well, it is – you never know until you try. Patient: Yeah. Okay.

Family Member: Your urine. Patient: Yeah. Okay. No problem. Doctor: But you’re not leaking or anything? Patient: No. Doctor: How many times you up at night to pee? Patient: Hum, once or twice at night. Doctor: Okay. Have you been to the hospital since I saw you? Patient: No. Doctor: So you feel like you’re holding your own, getting worse, feeling better? Patient: Yeah, hum, I’m holding my own. Doctor: Any falls? Patient: No.

Patient: Yeah, there is – Doctor: African Americans Patient: Yes, very much so. I talked to her about all of it because— Doctor: Who’s going to look at these films, I don’t know. But someone’s going to look at them, and there’s science going to be done. I don’t know what it is, but – Patient: If there, uh, Doctor: How many times I blinked at you or something. I’m not sure what the – Patient: In part of the work that I do, she was --- I do race disability Doctor: Yeah, you told me that, yeah. Patient: So, they were interested in what, how I answered questions. Anyway. Doctor: Alright. You did a good job. You get an A. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: I don’t even know if this things still working. Family Member: We’re all movie, movie stars now.

Patient: No. It won’t be a couple of months. We couldn’t handle a couple of months. Doctor: Okay. We’ll shoot for less than a month. How about that? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. How you doing on the XTANDI? Not too bad? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. You look great. But anything compared to last time when you weren’t feeling so hot and your blood sugar was…… YOU LOOK GREAT! (Laughs) Patient: Well, I feel good. Doctor: Okay. We’ll have to see what your PSA is but obviously last time it’s gone down, and I’m thrilled. Patient: Well, let’s hope it’s gone down. So we haven’t gotten it back? Doctor: Um hum. Not from today but we’ll call ya’. Family Member: Oh yeah. I need to give the nurse the new phone number. Doctor: Oh. Well holler to him. He’ll write it and pass it on to K___ too just in case.

Patient: No. You’ve got it all. Doctor: So I’m going to put Bell’s palsy on here. You said it’s lopsided? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And you’ve had, not had any issues with depression in the past or anxiety? Patient: No. Doctor: Any acid reflux? Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: Ever have a seizure? Patient: No. Doctor: Stroke? Patient: Nope. Doctor: Sleep apnea?

Patient: I don’t think that did anything for me. Doctor: Right, yeah, yeah. Patient: And so after a couple of months, he said, “This isn’t working,- Doctor: Yes. Patient: -so let’s not continue it.” Doctor: Right. You know the good part is there’s always new stuff coming down the pike. Patient: There is. Doctor: And we’ve just got to keep you upright and functioning and enjoying life- Patient: Right Doctor: -and keep those options open. Patient: But the other thing, I mean this is kind of the other side of what you have to deal with- Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And with time, like more months, like up to September. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: In September if that that – if nothing happens, then we can go to another ah step Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: in treating the sexual function. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Injections into the penis. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Uh but that’s I don’t know if I gave you a book about that or not. Patient: Uh no, no you just you know you discussed the options. Doctor: Well I’ll get you some literature about that, but injections would be the next step.

Patient: Well you took me off of this thing… Doctor: Yes, yes. Family Member: Yes. That’s the other question. Patient: So… Doctor: So we’re gonna try to put you back on. Patient: Okay, that’s fine… Doctor: ‘Cause I don’t think it’s related… Patient: Right. Doctor: …however all these other doctor’s appointments all gotta go right according to plan… Family Member: Yes. Doctor: …so that we don’t make you worse because there’s still no matter what some clearance of you know, any of the medicines are always somewhat cleared, some percentage by the kidneys so… Patient: Right I understand that.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -to say that there is absolutely has the same effect as chemotherapy on PSA or it has the effect like Xofigo. So that’s something we’ll find out but I think if everything else is lining up that you’re doing well on this treatment. I don’t think we should just make a decision and jump off the treatment is the PSA is going up. Patient: Oh. Family Member: That makes sense. And what if his bone scan is positive? The one he just had. Is the… Doctor: Yeah so if it shows progression, then I think we have to look – change gears to a different treatment and that’s where all those options come in whether to do chemotherapy, whether to do Xofigo or whether to do that new hormonal pill. So any of those are equally good options. Family Member: Okay. Patient: I see. Family Member 2: So you don’t have any more questions K___? Family Member: I don’t think so. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah I know, she said that. Family Member 2: We’re glad that she was able to come. Doctor: Yeah, no that’s wonderful. Yeah it’s important to… What do you think or are you ready to bail from this treatment? Patient: Yeah.
